poem:
Title: "Catwalk Canticle"

Fashion-month flutters, a flamboyant fan,
Blinking New York bright, the dance began,
Parisian whispers on Milan's cheek,
London's laughter, chic and sleek.
Debutante dreams, comeback quirk, 
In cotton's whisper, velvet's smirk.
What trickles down, not mere attire,
But silent sonnets of brazen desire.
Tucked and tweaked - life's unending game,
We, the players, never the same.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Debuts, comebacks, street-style inspo – what to expect from London, Paris, Milan and New York fashion weeks Happy fashion month to all that celebrate! On Friday, the first of the big four womenswear fashion weeks kicks off in New York, hitting play on a month-long schedule of shows, spectacle and drama. Which trends will trickle down and start to surreptitiously influence what we buy or borrow or the way we tuck and tweak our outfits". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
